msDesc.head:
Letter from
Maria Edgeworth

div.p:
Now that you are a great man at the head
of the Paving Board of all Ireland you may
guess without even being a born American
that every one who can will claim cousin
ship with you - Whether all will have their
claim allowed or have as good a right to claim
kindred I leave to your Honorable self as
the head of the Honble
Honorable paving board to deter
mine determine

My present suit is in favour of a youth
who is neither kith nor kin to me, and whom
I have never seen and of whom I know
nought excepting that he is nephew to a man
of whom I know a great deal of good -
viz James Kelly of Gourte & Kilcoursey - one of
our very best tenants - James Kelly entreats
me to write to you in favor of a nephew of his
Mr. Richard Jackson - one of the Jacksons of
Killogue - This young man had a small pro
perty property but his affairs having become embarrassed
(as affairs somehow or other are apt to do) he
wishes - very naturally, to get into some good

little snug place or situation by which he
could live; and he has a notion that in the
paving board you could just shuste him -
I have represented to my friend James Kelly
that I really cannot write a letter of
recommen
dation
recommendation for a man of whose qualifications & cha
racter character I know nothing - But that I am ready
to give his nephew an introduction to you
and that I advise Kelly to go up to Dublin
& vouch for his nephew himself to you -
This he will do - and would set out to do this
day but that a fair at which he must buy or
sell comes in the way, and he could not set
out for a day or two without great loss - Mean
time Meantime he wishes that you would be so kind
to let his nephew see you that you may judge
by examining him externally & internally whe
=ther whether he is fit for any situation in which you
could employ him - The young man is now
in Dublin & every day at Mr. Webbs office where
Kelly thinks all the world must have business
or may be likely to resort - By my counsel how-
ever however
Kelly writes to his nephew
Richd
Richard Jackson
desir
ing desiring him to call on Major Edgeworth at the Paving
Board -

Do what your conscience will allow you
to do for him to oblige

postscript.p:
Kelly will be in Town It is reasonable to believe that "Town" here is referring to Edgeworthstown. in a few days & will
wait upon you with his nephew in case
the youth should not have the courage to present
himself without an introduction. But he is
not a true-born Irishman if courage fails him
- so far - Pray do not give away all the
multitude of places which, (as Kelly conceives
you have to give before he can reach Dublin
& make his own representations for his nephew
- the most weighty of which is that he would
go security for him. I believe -
